overview_of_class: This course investigates the description, evaluation and representation of Asia in Russian writings of the 19th and the 20th century, with a specific focus on East Asia. We will engage with the notion of "Russian orientalism" in consideration of both the narrower and broader sense of the word: We will look at the development of Russian oriental studies and its relationship with the nation- and empire-building in Russian history. More importantly, we will read orientalism as a system of knowledge, opinions, judgments and hypotheses about Asia that was formed and transformed in the artistic, philosophical and journalistic writings by Russian authors. Questions to be discussed include: To what extent is Edward Said's idea of orientalism applicable to the history of Russian writings about Asia? Is it possible to talk about a "Russian occidentalism" that corresponds and counterbalances the orientalism? Does Russian orientalism draw a line between the orients within and without Russia? Authors to be read include: Vasilii Vasil'ev, Konstantin Leontiev, Vladimir Solovyov, Andrey Bely, Nikolai Gumilev, Velimir Khlebnikov, Boris Pilnyak, Sergei Tretyakov, etc.
